Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I glanced at the clock as I scrubbed the bathroom tiles, sweat beading on my forehead. The manager had just reminded me that every corner needed to be spotless today—no shortcuts, no missed spots. I could already hear her voice in my head, “We have guests coming, everything must shine.” My hands moved faster, but the grime in the grout was stubborn, and I still had two more rooms to deep clean. 

But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in twenty minutes. I was supposed to be there on time, ready to help set up for the community lunch. I knew the others could cover for me if I was late, but I hated the idea of letting them down. They counted on me to be reliable, to show up when I said I would. 

I felt torn, my mind racing between the expectation to leave every room immaculate and the commitment I’d made to the volunteer team. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment of my manager against the trust of my fellow volunteers, both demanding more than I could give at once.
